data.text: Advice on Biking Through Grizzly Country

Need some advice. I'm an experienced bike traveler, but I've never ridden in grizzly country. This July, I will be following the Lewis and Clark trail W>E starting at the coast, taking a detour up to the Coeur d'Alene trail in Idaho, and back down to Missoula MO. I may be wild-camping at times and definitely in some state campgrounds. What do I need to know about bears? Best defenses? I will NOT be carrying a firearm. I WILL have bar spray, a stun gun, and an air horn (Will an air-horn deter a bear?) Am I more likely to encounter a bear camping? or on the road? Any advice is welcome! THANKS!

https://www.nps.gov/yell/planyourvisit/campinginbearcountry.htm
Camp in Bear Country - Yellowstone National Park (U.S. National Park Service)

data.text: Bear spray and an air horn are good deterrents. Probably the most important thing is to not store your food in your tent. I'd get a bear proof canister such as Bearvault. Bear resistant bags are not bear proof. Odor resistant bags won't block odors that will accumulate on the outside of the bag. You can also do a proper bear hang. Grizzlies cannot climb trees well (unlike black bears, which are extremely proficient), so climbing a tree is actually a reasonable way to get away from grizzlies. Be aware of your surroundings and try not to surprise a momma with cubs.
data.author: Kristin Hamann

data.text: some grizzlies can climb trees. Not a fool proof method for a get away!

data.text: Don't sleep with hot dogs in your tent! That's actually the advice I got from the old timers up in Alaska. I mean it's a good place to start but... My strategy in real bear country was to cook, eat, and store my food (in a bear canister!) before I made camp. I would usually do all this a quarter mile away, at least, from where I slept. It was overkill, but it was what I needed to sleep well as a solo rider.

data.text: This sounds like an EPIC trip and I hope you keep us posted with pics. I ride and camp in bear country quite a bit..and my two cents will probably be echoed throughout this thread but here goes... 1) I keep something jingley on my at all times (I have a metal key chain on my beaner that clinks as I walks or ride. You want the bear to know you're coming rather than take one by surprise. 2) No food or anything scented in your tent. No toothpaste, no snacks, etc. 3) Hang your food (away from your tent) - better yet a bear canister or bear box (if you stay at a campground that has em') 4) I carry a road flare with me- in my head it makes sense as a deterrent to something big like a bear or a wild boar.. but I haven't had to light it yet. They're cheap and lightweight and I keep one in the extra outside pocket of my pannier. 5) Don't cook near your tent and don't get food on your clothing. Here's a handy infographic

data.text: Traveling deep into bar country I received many warnings and advice aplenty. The main thing that was consistent it's that bears don't like surprises and when they have warning, they like to shy away on their own. I had a number of encounters some cute and interesting but none that.... In retrospect.... Were dangerous but, a couple times, my imagination got the better of me. I was bear sniffed inside my tent early in the morning, I acknowledged my presence with a quiet bear prayer I learned from a First Nations friend.... The bear snorted and, respecting the prayer, turned instantly to the lake and padded quietly away. Another time, I rode up to a small black bear eating berries at the side of the trail... She was not impressed and just continued eating, I wasn't sure about a momma bear and I made noise to announce my presence..... No response.... So, I rode forward to the bear, and, as I approached within about 20 feet I hollered, the bear turned and launched itself into the trunk of a tree, hanging on about two feet above ground.....I would have stopped and played with the little bear but..... Uncertain about a momma bear, I rolled past with a clear intention to travel on. Never once did I think about spraying a bear when I encountered them ...I did, however, spray an annoying and aggressive raccoon that was socialized to not fear people.

data.text: Once upon a time the Spirit of God went before men in battle, but that most ancient technology has been replaced by fear and wicked material devices that kill instead. EVERY creature in existence can attune to the Spirit, and it is our only real "defense" that allows us to communicate with all life forms in this chronically ill world. Learn to speak the divine language and not fear death, otherwise the critters will sense it and there will always be animosity between species. Guns do nothing except taint the conscience (if it's even present), and make things exponentially worse for everyone in the long run. I've personally been unarmed and in close proximity with many of these magnificent creatures, and can say emphatically that they are far more receptive to kindness than we've been led to believe. Use "common" sense though and keep all of your food in special containers designed to keep smells in and bears out, and show utmost respect for their homes as you would expect anyone else to show in yours. But if you insist on a weapon, I'd recommend getting a can of bear spray and only use it when absolutely necessary. The blue plastic container on my rig is a BV500 bear vault, and has become a permanent and indispensable part of my setup. There are others of varying shapes and sizes, but I've grown quite fond of this one because it's a great place to do laundry and also makes a nifty drum when empty. Not to mention that it holds a considerable amount of food, and after several years of owning it there have been zero instances of critters ravaging the food supply. It's also got 4 grooves around the center for attaching rope, so it can be hung from a tree when necessary.

All that to say, we heard about bear issues around us before and after and the only bear encounter we had was in Yellowstone where a large Black bear popped out 100' in front us. He wasn't interested in us. We kept our bear spray in our front bottle holder so it was close, we camped bear smart and asked the good Lord to keep us safe. Don't sleep with ANYTHING smellable in your tent. Candy,gum,toothpaste, deodorant, nothing! Store it in a tree at least 100 yds from your tent. In alot if the campgrounds up there, they have bear boxes. Just be smart and don't get lazy.

data.text: Carry bear spray and, remember, all bears would rather avoid human interaction. The only time I’ve experienced a bear on-trail while riding was right at dusk- when they tend to be arousing from naps and starting to forage. Having encountered Grizzlies in the greater Yellowstone area, I’ve had only 1 approach my tent at night, and he made a LOT of noise- sniffing and grunting. Rarely are they aggressive, in spite of the sensationalized stories you read and hear of. Instead, on trails while hiking, I’ve encountered bears who were quite aloof and seemed to find me nothing but an annoyance. While traveling/camping in bear country, make sure to hang my food bag about 50 yards from my tent, as high up in a tree as I could get it was important.
data.author: Val Boggs

data.text: Cook a mile or so down the trail away from where you will be sleeping. Have a bear canister. Don't where fruity fragrances or shampoo. Avoid brightly colored tents. Make noise from a distance but don't startle a bear. Have bear spray just in case.
data.author: Daren Eaken

data.text: I've noticed a few other posts that share my ideology so I'll throw mine in to increase the vote count. I've ridden / camped plenty in bear country. I follow this strict regimen: 1) about an hour or so before I intend to stop riding and camp, I stop and do all my cooking. 2) Do all necessary cleanup of dishes, cooking gear. 3) Pack any unused food back into bear-safe container (I have also used marine, water-tight, roll-top bag for this). 4) Pack any trash into another airtight bag / container. 5) Get back on the road and ride for another hour. 6) BEFORE setting up camp, find a spot to store bear-safe food container at least 100 meters from camp site. 7) Store trash container 100 meters in different direction. This sounds like a lot of trouble but, like all camping tasks on the road, it gets easier once you establish the habit. Following this regimen I haven't had a single unpleasant or scary bear incident in the wild. In my tent I keep the bear spray and mini compressed air foghorn close at hand but I've never had occasion to use either.
data.author: Robert Tolar
